subject: Public Speaking
title: Thatcher's The Lady's Not for Turning
description: A quick, practical guide to Thatcher's The Lady's Not for Turning.

hook.text: In 1980, Britain's economy was crashing and her own party wanted Margaret Thatcher to reverse her policies.

buildup.text: At the party conference, she delivered one line that defined her leadership: the lady's not for turning.

discovery.text: The phrase was a pun on a play title, but its meaning was steel-clear: she would not compromise under pressure.

twist.text: The stubbornness the line celebrated was both her greatest strength and eventually her political downfall.

climax.text: The line showed that a single memorable phrase can define a leader's entire brand â€” for better and worse.

punchline.text: One sentence became her entire political identity.

quiz.question: What did Thatcher's 'not for turning' phrase communicate?
options: Absolute refusal to reverse her policies under pressure
